Problem:
Examine a complex valued function \\(z(t) = x(t) + iy(t)\\), where \\(x(t)\\) and \\(y(t)\\) are governed by the system of differential equations \\(\\dot{x} = Ax\\) and \\(\\dot{y} = By\\), respectively. Here A and B are constant matrices. We consider the impact of the integral transform \\(F[z](s) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-st}z(t)\\, dt\\), where s is a complex variable.

If the integral transform \\(F[z](s)\\) is applied to the functions \\(x(t)\\) and \\(y(t)\\) at \\(t = 0\\), and then the systems are allowed to evolve under their respective equations without further intervention, will \\(F[z](s)\\) at some s be the same as if the systems were directly evolved and then transformed?
Explanation: The linearity and time invariance of integral transforms and linear differential equations mean that applying the transform at the initial state (t=0) or after evolution yields the same result due to the properties of convolution in the Laplace transform domain.
